Lower fees unlock scale, but they also lower the cost of abuse. 

Cheap transactions make it easier to automate scam flows, rotate wallets, split funds and move value faster after social engineering attacks.
For platforms, rising activity is not just growth. 
It increases the need for real time risk assessment at execution, when transactions are cheap and fast, prevention has to be just as fast

Ethereum ( $ETH) set a new activity record

On January 17, the 7-day moving average of transactions on the Ethereum network reached 2.43 million ‚Äî a new all-time high.

The growth has continued since mid-December after the Fusaka update. The main reason is low fees: the average gas fee has fallen to a record $0.15.

However, there is a downside ‚Äî because transactions are cheap, less ETH is being burned. Right now, the total supply of ETH is growing by about 0.8% per year.

#Macro Insights#

Over $850 million in liquidations in one day

In the last 24 hours, more than $852 million was liquidated in the crypto market, with most losses coming from long positions.

The trigger was comments by Donald Trump about Greenland and threats of new trade tariffs against the EU. The crypto market reacted later ‚Äî the drop started after Japanese markets opened and U.S. futures began trading.

Ethereum is having a rare grown-up moment
For years, the roadmap was simple: more layers, more scale, more users. Now, Vitalik Buterin is pushing the opposite idea - protocol simplicity.
His point is sharp: over time,
SETH has
accumulated legacy code, design compromises, and complexity that make the network harder to understand, maintain, and safely run. Left unchecked, this creates risk.
The key test? The "walkaway test." Ethereum should keep working even if today's core devs disappear. New teams must be able to understand the protocol without insider knowledge. Otherwise, decentralization quietly breaks.
Vitalik also warns about the "High Priest" problem: If only a handful of cryptography experts can explain how the protocol works, users are forced to trust them and the system is no longer truly trustless.
This doesn't mean deleting the past. Legacy features can move out of the core, handled via smart contracts, account abstraction, or isolated environments. Even the EVM could eventually run inside a simpler system.
Big shift:
$ETH is no longer trying to do
everything. It's evolving into a lean, auditable hyperstructure that does the right things, securely - for decades to come.
